title: How to Coat a Thanksgiving Turkey with Sage Butter

parts.name: Preheating the Oven and Making the Sage Butter

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C).
steps.description: Turn the oven on and adjust the temperature setting. Place the oven rack in the lower third of the oven so there is enough room for the turkey.

steps.headline: Chop the sage finely.
steps.description: Rinse 24 fresh sage leaves under cool, running water. Pat the leaves dry with a paper towel and gather them in a pile on a chopping board. Use a sharp knife to finely slice the leaves into small pieces.

steps.headline: Mix together unsalted butter, sage leaves, kosher salt, and black pepper.
steps.description: Place 1/2 cup (113 g) of unsalted butter, the chopped sage leaves, 1/4 tsp (1.5 g) of kosher salt, and 1/4 tsp (0.6 g) of freshly ground black pepper into a small bowl. Use a fork to combine the ingredients until they are smooth. Use room temperature butter, as it’s softer and easier to mix.

steps.headline: Place stuffing into the neck cavity if desired.
steps.description: Either purchase premade stuffing or make your own using breadcrumbs, spices, and meat. Fold open the neck flap and place spoonfuls of stuffing into the body cavity. Spread out the stuffing so it evenly fills the cavity. Adding stuffing is optional. The turkey will still taste great without it!

steps.headline: Use your hands to gently separate the turkey’s skin.
steps.description: Find the neck opening and slide your fingers between the skin and the meat. The skin will easily separate away from the meat. Carefully push your fingers around the whole turkey until all of the skin around the legs and breasts is loose. The loose skin will look like a pocket. Be careful not to accidentally rip through the skin.

steps.headline: Place the sage butter under the turkey’s skin.
steps.description: Take small handfuls of the sage butter and place it in between the turkey's skin and the meat. Move the sage butter around under the turkey's skin with your fingers to try and get an even distribution. Cover all of the meat that you can reach with the sage butter. If there is any leftover butter, spread it over the outside of the skin too. Placing the sage butter under the turkey's skin keeps the flavor contained in the turkey as it cooks. This also stops the butter from spilling into the pan.

steps.headline: Massage the turkey to spread the butter out.
steps.description: Place your hands on the outside of the turkey’s skin and rub the skin gently to maneuver the sage butter around. Try to spread out the butter evenly and look under the skin to check if you missed any spots.

steps.headline: Place the turkey in a roasting pan.
steps.description: Arrange a roasting rack inside a large, flameproof pan. Lift the turkey onto the rack and rest it breast-side up.

steps.headline: Tuck the turkey’s wings underneath its back.
steps.description: Hold a wing and raise that side of the turkey by 1–2 in (2.5–5.1 cm). Tuck the wing under its back and then gently lower the turkey again to hold the wing in place. Repeat this for the other wing. Tucking in the wings stops them from burning and cooks the turkey evenly.

steps.headline: Tie the drumsticks together with kitchen twine.
steps.description: Cut an 8 in (20 cm) piece of kitchen twine. Cross the drumsticks at the thinnest part and secure these with the twine. Tie a knot to make sure that the twine doesn’t come undone.

steps.headline: Roast the turkey for 3 hours, rotating the pan every 30 minutes.
steps.description: Place the turkey in the oven with the legs pointing towards the back. Turn the pan 90° every half hour and baste the turkey with pan drippings if you like crispy skin. As the turkey cooks, check that the legs or breast aren't browning faster than the rest of the meat. Cover the legs or breast with foil if you notice this happening to help the meat cook more evenly.

steps.headline: Remove the turkey when the thigh temperature reaches 170 °F (77 °C).
steps.description: Begin testing the temperature of the turkey every 15 minutes during the last 1 hour. Insert an instant-read thermometer into the thickest part of the thigh and remove the turkey when you get the right reading. Turkey tends to take 15-20 minutes per 1 lb (0.45 kg) to cook. The thigh juices will run clear when the turkey is ready.

steps.headline: Rest the turkey for 30-60 minutes before serving.
steps.description: Keep the turkey in the roasting pan while it rests and only remove it when it’s time to carve. This stops the juices from spilling and keeps the meat from going dry.
